Future work the authors indicate or strongly suggest includes:

• Evaluating hydraulic fracturing’s role in triggering earthquakes. Although they note such activity does occur in the Raton Basin, they have not specifically quantified its impact on seismicity.

• Examining potential en echelon fault splays and their relationship to larger faults like Vermejo Park and Tercio, as well as clarifying whether the Vermejo Park fault is indeed one continuous structure.

Based on the discussion in the text, the principal recommendation for future work is to refine how basement hydrogeology (especially basement diffusivity) is incorporated into numerical models. Because pore‐pressure results can change substantially depending on whether basement diffusivity is assumed to be homogeneous and low or to decay with depth, more realistic basement representations are critical. Specifically:

• More Detailed Basement Characterization:  
  – Collect or utilize additional field data (e.g., well tests, geophysical logs) to constrain the depth‐dependent permeability and diffusivity, rather than relying on a single low‐diffusivity value.  
  – Investigate lateral and vertical heterogeneities in basement properties that could affect pore‐pressure diffusion pathways.

• Expanded Sensitivity Studies:  
  – Systematically test how fault zone properties (fault diffusivity, sealing vs. conductive behavior) interact with depth‐variable basement diffusivities.  
  – Examine how uncertainties in reservoir parameters, especially at greater depths, propagate into model predictions of timing and magnitude of seismicity.

• Improved Temporal and Spatial Resolution:  
  – Acquire higher‐resolution spatial data on fault geometry and basement structure to capture where and how fluid pressures migrate into faults.  
  – Refine the timing of pore‐pressure triggering by integrating local seismic data and well injection histories to better match early‐stage seismicity.

• Incorporation of Hydrogeologic Heterogeneities:  
  – Include possible interconnected fracture networks or stratigraphic complexities that can significantly alter pressure migration in basement rocks.

Overall, the study highlights that basement diffusivity plays a decisive role in modeling fluid‐injection‐induced seismicity. Future models should account for realistic depth‐variable basement properties, better fault zone characterization, and potential hydrogeologic heterogeneities to yield more accurate predictions of pore‐pressure buildup and resulting seismic activity.
